subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: The European Commission’s Green Deal, unveiled in December 2019, sets the pace for emissions reduction for European Union member states to reach net zero by 2050. Italy plans to lower its emissions by 43% from 2005 levels by 2030 in sectors covered by the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), and by 33% for sectors that fall outside the EU ETS.

Decarbonization of the power sector is at the center of Italy’s low-carbon strategy. As part of its 2019 National Energy and Climate Plan, the country laid out an ambition to achieve 26% of electricity generation from renewables in 2020, rising to 55% in 2030. It also set out a target for 30% of final energy consumption to come from renewables in 2030, from 17% in 2020.

To boost renewables deployment, the Ministry of Economic Development enforced a new decree implementing a technology-neutral auction system in July 2019. The auction program aims to procure 6.2 gigawatts (GW) of renewable energy capacity over seven rounds to meet Italy’s 2030 targets.
The country is also striving to increase grid interconnection with the rest of Europe and has set ambitious goals for clean hydrogen. Its target is to build 5GW of electrolyzer capacity by 2030.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: EU members submit a joint Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, outlining the bloc’s plan to help achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement. The EU’s initial NDC committed to lower emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels. The updated NDC submitted in December 2020 strengthened that target to a 55% reduction in emissions by 2030.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Italy has set a target to phase out all coal plants by 2025 as part of its National Energy Strategy. The target is non-binding and Italy must implement the phase-out through executive measures. Since the onset of the European energy crisis in August 2021, Italy has revived 2.3GW of coal capacity that was previously mothballed to ensure security of supply.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: The country passed legislation in 2019 to revive its renewables sector, which had been struggling since the end of utility-scale solar subsidies in 2013. It decided to host seven technology-neutral auctions to procure 6.2 gigawatts (GW) of renewable capacity, with auction winners securing 20-year contracts that guarantee them a power price. As of October 2022, all seven rounds of auctions had awarded a total of almost 3.4GW of contracts to wind and solar generators. The country must ramp up construction to meet its 2030 target for 55% of electricity generation to come from renewables.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Italy’s power market is geographically divided into six zones, and spot prices vary according to the bidding zones. Wholesale power prices reflect the marginal cost of generation at the zonal level. Prices only converge to the national single price, known as the PUN, when there is no congestion. Italy has recently improved transmission network bottlenecks between the Northern and Southern regions of the country, leading to power price convergence across the bidding zones.

Italy’s wholesale and retail power prices are among the highest in Europe. High retail power prices reflect Italy’s dependency on gas, putting consumers at a disadvantage. On the flip side, high wholesale power prices combined with good wind and solar resources are attracting subsidy-free renewable projects.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Gas plants accounted for 46% of Italy’s electricity generation in 2021, followed by coal at 7%, hydro at 16%, and wind and solar at a combined 16%. The country has committed to phase out coal by 2025 and announced plans to increase its interconnection and renewables capacity. In 2022, Italy revived 2.3GW of coal plants that were previously mothballed as response to the energy crisis to provide additional supply.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The gas boom seen in Italy in the early 2000s have led the country to suffer from overcapacity and underutilization As a result, many Italian gas plants struggle to make a profit and are at risk of closure. The country’s intention to phase out coal by 2025 would reduce some of the overcapacity in the market, although this is part of a non-binding energy plan. The revival of coal plants in 2022 for energy security also risks delaying coal closure, which may undermine the operation of gas plants. The recently approved capacity market has given marginal generators a boost. Italy held its first auction in 2019 and awarded 30GW of capacity contracts to existing gas generators and 5GW for new build.

subsections.title: EV market
text: Italy is aiming to have 4 million electric vehicles (EV) and 2 million hybrid vehicles on its roads by 2030. These targets are ambitious considering the relatively small size of its current EV fleet, estimated to be around 237,258 at the end of 2021.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The country has subsidies and grants to support the growth of EVs. In 2018, it passed a stimulus bill that increased the maximum EV subsidy to €6,000 ($5,874) for battery-electric vehicles and €3,500 for hybrid-electric and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. In addition, the bill included provisions for a scrappage scheme.

Italy also has an exemption from annual circulation tax (ownership tax) for a period of five years from the date when the EV was first licensed and, starting from the end of that five-year period, a 75% reduction of the circulation tax. There is also a state policy that applies to certain provinces whereby EVs are exempt from road tax for five years.

As well as incentives to encourage the purchase of EVs, there are also support schemes to enhance EV charging infrastructure across the country. The European Investment Bank (EIB) is working alongside Enel to finance around 14,000 new EV charging stations that will be installed throughout Italy over the next four years.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: There are no significant barriers to increasing EV adoption in Italy.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: Italy has seen significant gains in energy efficiency over the past decade. Moving forward, the country has planned for new measures to implement its National Fund for Energy Efficiency, which will support Italy to reach its 2030 targets.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: Italy provides training, awareness activities and tax breaks to reduce emissions from the buildings sector. The latest ‘Ecobonus’ scheme offers a tax deduction of 50-110% for expenses related to the refurbishment of existing buildings, energy efficiency requalification of buildings and installation of renewable heat technologies.

Heat pumps are expected to play a pivotal role in Italian households’ transition to a lower-carbon heating system. There are both private and public sector incentives to invest in cogeneration and district heating through a price-based scheme known as “Conto Termico”. Heat pumps, biomass and solar thermal are eligible technologies, and the incentive is granted for a period of two to five years. Incentives are paid either annually or in a single amount up to a maximum €5,000.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Administrative issues and bureaucratic processes have slowed down the uptake of public funding available for energy efficiency renovations.
